questions.text: The heart receives its blood supply from the coronary arteries, and coronary blood flow can vary under different physiological conditions. Subendocardial coronary blood flow is significantly reduced or temporarily stops during which phase of the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

During systole, the cardiac muscle contracts, and intraventricular pressure rises, especially in the left ventricle. This compresses the subendocardial vessels, reducing or even stopping blood flow in that layer.

  • The subendocardial region (the inner layer of the heart wall) is most vulnerable to ischemia.
  • During diastole, the myocardium relaxes and coronary perfusion peaks, especially in the subendocardial areas.

Explanation for other options:

Diastole (Option A): Coronary blood flow increases during diastole, especially in the left ventricle, because ventricular pressure is low and vessels are not compressed.

Remains intact in both phases (Option C): Not true, especially for subendocardial flow in the left ventricle, which is compromised during systole.

Couldn't say (Option D): There is clear physiological evidence showing reduced subendocardial flow during systole.

Key Takeaway:

  • Normal Coronary blood flow: 60-80 ml/100gm/min or 250 ml/min.
  • The peak left coronary flow occurs at the end of isovolumetric relaxation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient was admitted to the emergency department for chest pain. Some methods can be utilised to detect coronary blood flow. From the following list, which method works on selective increase in uptake by infarcted tissue, showing as hotspots on the scintigram of the chest?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

99m-Tc-PYP (technetium 99) is when administered selectively taken up by infarcted cardiac tissue and appears as hotspots in scintigrams of the chest.

  • It binds to calcium deposits in dead myocardial cells and produces "hot spots" on the scintigram (a type of nuclear imaging).
  • This is particularly helpful in diagnosing recent myocardial infarction (MI).
  • Several techniques utilising radionuclides detected with radiation detectors over the chest have been used to study regional blood flow in the heart and to detect areas of ischemia and infarction.
  • Coronary flow at rest in humans is about 250 mL/min (5% of the cardiac output).
  • 133 Xeadministration can be combined with coronary angiography for detailed analysis of coronary blood flow.

Explanation for other options:

Kety method (Option A): In the Kety method, a catheter is inserted into the coronary sinus and N2O content is measured in coronary venous blood, which has no role in infarct detection.

Thallium 201 (Option B): It is pumped into the cardiac cells. After 10-15 minutes, 201Tl distribution is directly proportional to myocardial blood flow. Infarcted areas appear as "cold spots" (reduced uptake), not hot spots. It detects ischaemia and perfusion defects, not infarct uptake.

questions.text:
Among the following factors, which increases the coronary blood flow?
1. Increase in local concentration of CO2
2. Intracoronary cyanide injection
3. Increase in adenosine
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All three given factors increase the coronary blood flow.

  • The coronary blood flow is not only influenced by the pressure changes but also by some neural and chemical factors. It helps in the autoregulation of the blood flow.

The following factors increase the coronary blood flow.

  • Lack of oxygen (hypoxia)
  • Increase level of metabolites (CO2, H+, K+, lactate) (Statement 1 is true)
  • Increase in adenosine (Statement 3 is true)
  • Increase in prostaglandins
  • Asphyxia
  • Intracoronary injection of cyanide (Statement 2 is true)
  • Occlusion followed by release of coronary blood flow (reactive hyperemia)

questions.text: Which of the following molecules released in coronary artery disease interferes with fibrinolysis via downregulation of plasmin generation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lipoprotein (a) has a direct relation with atherosclerosis. Lp(a) has an outer coat consisting of apo(a).

  • Lipoprotein(a) is structurally similar to plasminogen, the precursor of plasmin, which plays a key role in fibrinolysis(the breakdown of blood clots).
  • Lipoprotein(a) competes with plasminogen for binding sites, thereby inhibiting plasmin generation.
  • This impairs fibrinolysis, promoting thrombosis and contributing to atherothrombotic events in coronary artery disease (CAD).
  • The commonest cause of myocardial infarction is the atherosclerotic plaque in obese individuals.

Explanation for other options:

C-reactive protein (Option B): In myocardial infarction, there is an increase in C-reactive protein and other inflammatory markers in the blood, reflecting the inflammatory response to myocardial injury, but it does not directly interfere with fibrinolysis.

Creatine kinase-MB (Option C): Myocardial cell damage due to infarction leads to a rise in creatine kinase-MB (CK-MB), which is a marker of cardiac muscle injury, but not involved in fibrinolysis.

Troponin T (Option D): Levels of troponin T increase following myocardial infarction, serving as a sensitive and specific marker for cardiac muscle damage, but do not influence the fibrinolytic pathway.

Key Takeaway: Lipoprotein (a) has a direct relation with atherosclerosis. Lp(a) has an outer coat consisting of apo(a). It interferes with fibrinolysis by down-regulating plasmin generation.

choices.text: Blood flow in Common carotid arteries

questions.text: The image below demonstrates phasic blood flow through a specific set of vessels, where blood flow decreases during systole and increases during diastole. This pattern of blood flow is typically observed in which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Normally, the blood flow in arteries is constant. It doesn't change significantly, as shown in the graph, except for coronary vessels.
  • The coronary capillary flow in the left ventricle is low during systole, which is opposite to the flow in vascular beds elsewhere in the body. The reason for this phenomenon is the strong compression of the intramuscular blood vessels by the left ventricular muscle during systolic contraction.
  • During diastole, the cardiac muscle relaxes and no longer obstructs blood flow through the left ventricular muscle capillaries, so blood flows rapidly during all of the diastole.

questions.text: A patient who is 60 years old was admitted to the medical emergency department due to severe chest pain. ECG was done immediately, Patient was found to have a myocardial infarction. Which of the following treatments may increase the chance of mortality if surgery is indicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In acute myocardial infarction, antithrombotic agents are often given, but these can be problematic, leading to increased mortality due to bleeding if cardiac surgery is subsequently needed.

Explanation for other options:

Balloon Angioplasty (Option A): Percutaneous coronary intervention (balloon angioplasty is a comparatively safer procedure.

Angiography (Option C): It is an investigational procedure with minimal complications.

Coronary artery bypass grafting (Option D): CABG improves survival in selected MI patients (especially with multivessel disease). While it's invasive, it's indicated, not contraindicated.

choices.text: The sympathetic stimulation does not cause significant vasoconstriction
Local blood flow regulatory mechanisms are powerful
Above the mean arterial pressure of 70 mmHg, blood flow is easily maintained with regulatory mechanisms

questions.text: Among the following, which is true about the coronary and cerebral circulation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All of the above statements are true about coronary and cerebral circulation.

The primary purpose of blood flow regulation is to maintain the blood flow to the heart and brain.

  • So, even in case of a decrease in cardiac output, special mechanisms are there for cerebral and coronary circulation.
  • The sympathetic stimulation does not cause significant constriction of the cerebral or cardiac vessels. (Option A is true)
  • In addition, in both vascular beds, local blood flow autoregulation is excellent, which prevents moderate decreases in arterial pressure from significantly decreasing their blood flows. (Option B is true)
  • Blood flow through the heart and brain is maintained essentially at normal levels as long as the mean arterial pressure does not fall below about 70 mm Hg; even the blood flow in some other areas of the body might be decreased to as little as one-third to one-quarter normal by this time because of vasoconstriction. (Option C is true)

choices.text: Absence of the whole triple response
Absence of the red line only

questions.text: In a 37-year-old male patient, sympathectomy was done for a chronic pain condition. In this patient, what are the changes noted in the triple response?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A triple response is obtained by giving a firm stroke to the skin.
  • The triple response (as described by Lewis) includes:
    1. Red line -due to capillary dilation from direct mechanical stimulation
    2. Flare- due to axon reflex - mediated arteriolar dilation, involving intact sympathetic sensory nerves
    3. Wheal- due to increased capillary permeability mediated by histamine
  • After sympathectomy is done, there is no change in the triple response, as the local vasodilators play an important role in this reaction. (Option B ruled out)
  • Flare is absent in locally anesthetised skin and denervated skin after the sensory nerves have degenerated. (Option C ruled out)
  • This may occur due to axon reflex, which is a response in which impulses initiated in sensory nerves by the injury are relayed antidromically down other branches of the sensory nerve fibres.
  • White reactionis produced when the object is drawn lightly over the skin, leading to constriction of precapillary sphincters. It appears in about 15 seconds.
  • The red line is a direct capillary reaction and remains intact. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 59-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset weakness of the right limb. On evaluation, he is diagnosed with a stroke. Which of the following is the most common type of stroke?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ischaemic stroke is the most common type, accounting for approximately 85% of all strokes.

  • Among all causes of stroke most common is atherosclerosis, leading to narrowing of the cerebral vascular lumen.
  • It produces ischemic stroke due to reduced blood flow.

Explanation for other options:

Haemorrhagic stroke (Option C): In about 25% of stroke patients, haemorrhage due to rupture of blood vessels, or due to hypertension, leads to haemorrhagic stroke.

Embolic stroke (Option A): Embolic stroke occurs when a blood clot or debris travels from another part of the body and becomes lodged in an artery in the brain, blocking blood flow. Comparatively rarer than ischemic and haemorrhagic stroke.

Traumatic cerebrovascular accident (Option D): Accidents such as a fall, car crash, or sports-related injury can result in a traumatic brain injury (TBI) can cause stroke depending on the involvement of cerebral vessels. A very rare cause of stroke.

Key Takeaway:

Causes of stroke:

  1. Atherosclerosis- Most common cause.
  2. High Blood Pressure
  3. High Cholesterol
  4. Diabetes
  5. Smoking
  6. Obesity
  7. Physical Inactivity
  8. Excessive Alcohol Consumption
  9. Family History of Stroke
  10. Age
  11. Race and Ethnicity

questions.text: Which of the following neurosecretory substances produces vasoconstriction in the cerebral vessels?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neuropeptide Y is a neurosecretory substance that produces vasoconstriction in the cerebral vessels.

  • Postganglionic sympathetic neurons, which innervate cerebral blood vessels, have their cell bodies in the superior cervical ganglia; their endings contain norepinephrine and Neuropeptide Y in many neurons.
  • Postganglionic cholinergic neurons acting on the cerebral blood vessels contain acetylcholine, vasoactive intestinal peptide and peptide histidine methionine (PHM-27) in some neurons.
  • In distal cerebral arteries, sensory nerves (trigeminal ganglia) contain substance P, neurokinin A and calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP).

Explanation for other options:

Calcitonin gene-related peptide (Option A): Causes potent vasodilation, especially in the meningeal and cerebral vessels. It is implicated in migraine pathophysiology.

Substance P (Option B): It is a vasodilator involved in neurogenic inflammation.

Vasoactive intestinal peptide (Option C): Also a vasodilator, especially in the gastrointestinal tract and brain.

choices.text: Sudden marked increase in blood pressure

questions.text: Blood-brain barrier is very important to protect the brain from unwanted substances. Among the list, which is/are the causes of breakdown or breach in blood-brain
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All of the above given causes breach in blood-brain barrier.

The Blood-Brain Barrier (BBB) is a selective barrier formed by:

  • Tight junctions between non-fenestrated capillary endothelial cells
  • Basement membrane
  • Pericytes
  • Astrocyte foot processes

It protects the brain from pathogens, toxins, and fluctuating plasma composition, allowing only selective transport (e.g., glucose, amino acids via transporters; lipid-soluble substances via diffusion).

Circumventricular Organs (CVOs): Regions with no BBB, allowing blood components to influence brain function (Mnemonic: M SOAP)

  • Median eminence
  • Subfornical organ
  • Organum vasculosum of lamina terminalis (OVLT)
  • Area postrema
  • Posterior pituitary

Clinical examples of BBB disruption:

  • Stroke → vasogenic oedema
  • Hyperosmolar agents (e.g. mannitol) → increase permeability
  • Infections → cytokine-mediated endothelial damage
  • Injuries or tumours (new blood vessels develop, which do not develop the blood-brain barrier)
  • In case of marked or sudden increase in blood pressure

questions.text: Following image shows congenital defects in circulation. It is probably
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fallot tetralogy is the most common reason for blue babies. Most of the blood bypasses the lungs, so the aortic blood is mainly deoxygenated venous blood.
  • Four common abnormalities seen in Tetralogy of Fallot are
    1. The aorta originates from the right ventricle rather than the left, or it overrides a hole in the septum, receiving blood from both ventricles
    2. Pulmonary artery is stenosed, much lower than normal amounts of blood passing from the right ventricle into the lungs; instead, most of the blood passes directly into the aorta, thus bypassing the lungs.
    3. Blood from the left ventricle flows through a ventricular septal holeinto the right ventricle and then into the aorta or directly into the aorta that overrides this hole.
    4. Because the right side of the heart must pump large quantities of blood against the high pressure in the aorta, its musculature is highly developed, causing right ventricular hypertrophy.

Explanation for other options:

Patent ductus arteriosus (Option A): Causes a continuous "machinery murmur"; does not include VSD or overriding aorta.

Left ventricular hypertrophy (Option B): Typically due to systemic hypertension or aortic stenosis; not a congenital cyanotic defect.

Congenital valvular defect (Option C): May involve stenosis or regurgitation of valves but lacks the combination of four key anomalies seen in TOF.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man had a bacterial infection and developed septic shock. The doctor investigated the patient and found that the patient was in a progressive stage of shock. Among the following list, which are complications of the progressive stage of shock
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All of the above symptoms are complications of the progressive stage of shock.

  • When the arterial pressure falls low enough, coronary blood flow decreases below that required for adequate nutrition of the myocardium, weakening the heart muscle and decreasing the cardiac output further, causing cardiac depression. (Option A is true)
  • At a particular point, when diminished blood flow to the brain's vasomotor centre depresses the centre so much that it, too, becomes progressively less active and, finally, totally inactive, causing vasomotor failure. (Option B is true)
  • Not all the cells of the tissue have the same blood supply. More nutritive deficiency occurs around the venous ends of capillaries than elsewhere in the distal tissues, producing patchy necrosis. (Option C is true)

Key Takeaway:

Complications of the progressive stage of shock:

  • Cardiac depression
  • Vasomotor failure
  • Patchy tissue necrosis

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient was met with an accident. Due to severe blood loss, he progressed to haemorrhagic shock. The doctor prescribed the treatment for it. Which of the following might not help in case of haemorrhagic shock?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sympathomimetic drugs are not very valuable in haemorrhagic shock. Here, the sympathetic nervous system is already maximally activated by regulatory mechanisms. So, there is no additional benefit to it.

Explanation for other options:

Dextran transfusion (Option A): Dextran is a plasma substitute that increases the volume of plasma when administered into a blood vessel. It is definitely of help in haemorrhagic shock.

Administration of glucocorticoids (Option C): Glucocorticoids are helpful in all stages of shock as they increase the strength of the heart in the late stages of shock; stabilise the lysosomal cells.

Blood transfusion (Option D): This is the definitive treatment to restore oxygen-carrying capacity and circulating volume in haemorrhagic shock.

questions.text: There are various types of shock classified based on their underlying causes. Which of the following types of shock is typically classified as cold shock?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypovolemic shock is known as cold shock, in which the periphery becomes cold and pale (limbs) because hypovolemia causes hypotension.

The symptoms of hypovolemic shock are

  • Hypotension; a rapid, thready pulse, cold, pale, clammy skin, intense thirst, rapid respiration and restlessness.
  • Reduced pulse pressure(as the systolic pressure falls more than the diastolic pressure), but mean arterial pressure remains normal. It occurs due to a decrease in the rate of discharge of arterial baroreceptors, causing reflex tachycardia and vasoconstriction.
  • Tachycardiaoccurs to compensate for the demand and sympathetic stimulation.
  • Cyanosismay appear due to stasis in capillaries, especially in the periphery.
  • Anaerobic glycolysisoccurs due to inadequate perfusion. It causes the production of large amounts of lactic acid, leading to lactic acidosis.

Explanation for other options:

Vasogenic shock (Option A): Vasogenic shock occurs due to intense vasodilation, leading to increased peripheral blood flow.

Cardiogenic shock (Option B): Cardiogenic shock occurs due to decreased pumping ability of the heart, eg, Heart failure.

Septic shock (Option D): Septic shock occurs due to infection, e.g. peritonitis. Usually, there is high fever, vasodilatation, and high cardiac output due to infection, e.g. peritonitis. Usually, there is high fever, vasodilatation, and high cardiac output.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male is exposed to thermal burns and admitted to the emergency department for treatment. The patient lost too much fluid from his body, so he is in shock. Which of the following could probably help more in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient is suffering from hypovolaemic shock secondary to thermal burns. In burn injuries, the primary loss is from the plasma component of blood due to increased capillary permeability, leading to fluid shift from the intravascular to interstitial space. The result is reduced circulating blood volume without significant loss of red blood cells.

Plasma transfusion:

  • Plasma contains essential proteins like albumin and clotting factors, helping to restore oncotic pressure and intravascular volume.
  • It effectively replaces the fluid and protein loss seen in burns, thereby stabilising haemodynamics.

Explanation for other options:

Blood transfusion (Option A):

  • Useful when there is significant loss of red blood cells, as in haemorrhagic shock.
  • In burns, the RBC volume is usually preserved, so giving blood may lead to haemoconcentration and increased viscosity.

Concentrated serum albumin (Option C):

  • While albumin expands plasma volume, hyperoncotic solutions can draw more fluid from already compromised interstitial tissues, worsening tissue dehydration.
  • Risk of worsening oedema or renal injury is also higher if not carefully monitored.

Vasoconstrictor drugs (Option D):

  • These drugs increase vascular tone but are not first-line in hypovolaemic shock caused by fluid loss.
  • Without adequate volume resuscitation, vasoconstriction can further impair tissue perfusion and worsen outcomes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male visited the doctor for a routine checkup. He was diagnosed with hypertension. On evaluation, the Reynolds number for blood flow is found to be 2500. What can be the probable cause(s)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Normal blood flow through the major vessels is laminar. It can be calculated by calculating the Reynolds' number.

The Reynolds number (Re) is a dimensionless quantity used to predict the nature of fluid flow-whether it will be laminar (smooth) or turbulent.

Clinical Significance:

  • Re < 2000: Laminar flow (normal in most vessels)
  • Re > 2000: May indicate transition to turbulent flow
  • Re > 3000: May occur in large arteries or abnormal conditions like anaemia or high cardiac output states

Factors contributing:

High blood flow velocity (Option A): ↑ Velocity (v) directly increases Re. Seen in hypertension and hyperdynamic states.

Sudden sympathetic stimulation (Option B): Causes vasoconstriction, increased heart rate, and increased cardiac output-all leading to higher velocity and Re.

Atherosclerosis (Option C): Narrows the vessel diameter → increases local velocity (per continuity equation) and creates flow disturbances → increases Re.

questions.text: Blood flow through vessels exerts a force called shear stress along the longitudinal axis of the endothelium. This mechanical force plays a role in vascular physiology and gene expression. Which of the following genes is/are affected by shear stress?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All of the above genes are affected by shear stress

  • Change in shear stress and other physical variables, such as cyclic strain and stretch, produce marked changes in the expression of genes by endothelial cells.
  • The genes that are activated include those that produce growth factors, integrins, and related molecules, as shown in the figure.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues has the maximum hydraulic conductivity of capillaries?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hydraulic conductivity in capillaries means how easily the fluid can move through capillaries via their pores.

  • Different tissues have different hydraulic conductivities. In the Brain, the junction between the capillary endothelial cells is tighter, so the transport is very less, leading to the lowest hydraulic conductivity.
  • In kidney capillary endothelial cells are fenestrated, allowing even larger molecules to pass through the membrane. It has the highest hydraulic conductivity on the list.

The following is the list of hydraulic conductivities of capillaries in various organs.

choices.text: Windkessel vessels do not play a significant role in blood pressure regulation
Windkessel vessels have low elasticity and small diameter.
Windkessel vessels have high compliance and low resistance
Major veins are part of the windkessel vessels

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Windkessel vessels?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The aorta and larger arteries are called windkessel vessels. (Option D is false)
  • They are highly elastic, so they have high compliance. (Option B is false)
  • The blood ejected from major arteries and the aorta due to elastic tendency and higher compliance allows the steady flow of blood to the peripheral arteries.
  • This effect is called as windkessel effect.
  • Windkessel vessels play a significant role in blood pressure regulation. (Option A is false)
  • Due to their large diameter, they have less resistance. (Option B is false)

questions.text: Among the following, which is not the method used to measure the blood flow through vessels?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sphygmography is often used to record the pulse wave of the arterial pulse activity due to the systole of the heart and not used to measure the blood flow through vessels

Explanation for other options: The following methods are used to measure the blood flow through the vessels.

Plethysmography (Option B): This is used to measure the blood flow, usually through limbs. E.g., the forearm is sealed with a watertight chamber. Changes in the volume of the forearm demonstrate changes in the amount of blood and interstitial fluid. It displaces water, which is recorded in the volume recorder.

Doppler ultrasound (Option C): Doppler, along with ultrasound, helps to record high velocity blood flow through the ultrasound waves, which are reflected from RBCs, WBCs and picked up by the probe.

The Kety N2O method (Option D): This is specifically used to measure the coronary blood flow by inserting a catheter into the coronary sinus. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following structures requires the inclusion of surface tension when applying the Law of Laplace?
questions.solution:
Alveoli are spherical structures lined with a fluid film, creating surface tension at the air-liquid interface.

  • The Law of Laplace here is modified to include surface tension:
    P=2T/r
    P = pressure,
    T = surface tension, and
    r = radius
  • Surfactant reduces T, preventing alveolar collapse, especially in smaller alveoli.
  • In the alveolus, the pressure in the smaller alveolus (radius) is higher, so the smaller alveolus tends to collapse if the surfactant is not available to reduce the surface tension.

Explanation for other options:

Blood Vessels (Option A): Blood vessels follow the cylindrical form of the Law of Laplace:

T=P⋅r
T = wall tension,
P = internal pressure, and
r = vessel radius

Surface tension is not involved. Instead, vascular smooth muscle counters increased pressure to prevent rupture (e.g., in aneurysms).

Urinary Bladder (Option C): The urinary bladder behaves like a compliant hollow organ, and Laplace's law is applied to explain how wall tension changes with volume:

T=P⋅r

As volume increases, radius increases, but pressure does not increase proportionally due to detrusor muscle relaxation (law of Laplace helps explain this adaptation). No surface tension plays a role here.

Cardiac Ventricles (Option D): The left ventricle, like other heart chambers, follows the spherical/cylindrical Laplace law:

T=P*r/2h

(h = wall thickness)

This explains how increased radius (e.g. in dilated cardiomyopathy) increases wall stress. Again, surface tension is not involved.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male with chronic hypertension presents for a routine follow-up. During the consultation, the physician discusses the common causes of hypertension. Which of the following is not typically associated with the aetiology of hypertension?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cerebral thrombosis and haemorrhage are complications of hypertension, not a cause for hypertension.

  • Renin plays a major role in the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), which regulates blood pressure. Overactivity of this system is a known cause of secondary hypertension. (Option B is true)
  • Pheochromocytoma is acatecholamine-secreting tumour from the adrenal medulla, leading to episodic or sustained secondary hypertension due to excess norepinephrine and epinephrine. (Option C is true)
  • Chronic kidney disease impairs sodium and fluid handling and activates RAAS, making it a common cause of secondary hypertension. (Option D is true)

questions.text: Among the following the last ditch stand pressure control mechanism is
questions.solution:
Cushing's reaction is a special type of CNS ischemic response that results from increased pressure of the cerebrospinal fluid around the brain in the cranial vault.

  • CNS ischemic response operates principally as an emergency pressure control system that acts rapidly and powerfully to prevent further decrease in arterial pressure whenever blood flow to the brain decreases dangerously close to the lethal level. So-called last-ditch pressure control mechanism.
  • When the cerebrospinal fluid pressure rises to equal the arterial pressure, it compresses the whole brain, as well as the arteries in the brain, and cuts off the blood supply to the brain.
  • This action initiates a CNS ischemic response that causes the arterial pressure to rise.

Explanation for other options:

Baroreceptor reflex mechanism (Option A): A short-term blood pressure regulation mechanism. It responds rapidly to changes in arterial pressure but is not effective at extremely low pressures and does not protect against severe cerebral ischaemia.

Renin-angiotensin mechanism (Option B): A long-term regulator of blood pressure through vasoconstriction and fluid retention. It is effective but slower to act and not considered a "last-ditch" emergency response.

Chemoreceptor reflex mechanism (Option C): Responds to changes in blood oxygen, CO₂, and pH, stimulating respiratory and cardiovascular centres. It contributes to pressure regulation but becomes ineffective when cerebral perfusion is drastically reduced.

choices.text: Decreased secretion of Atrial natriuretic peptide

questions.text: A 46-year-old patient visited the doctor for a routine check-up. On examination, the patient has tachycardia. Further investigations revealed that increased heart rate might be due to increased arterial pressure. This is most likely related to which of the following reflexes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When blood volume is increased above normal, it increases the atrial pressure. Here, the Bainbridge reflex often increases heart rate despite the inhibitory actions of the baroreflexes.

  • It causes an increased heart rate to accommodate the increased venous return and prevent pooling in the heart.

Explanation for other options:

Atrial low-pressure receptor reflex (Option A): These are involved in volume regulation but generally work to decrease sympathetic tone, not increase HR.

Baroreceptor reflex (Option B): Responds to increased arterial pressure by causing bradycardia (not tachycardia) via parasympathetic activation.

Decreased secretion of ANP (Option D): Decreased secretion of ANP would lead to volume retention, but this is a hormonal response, not a reflex directly causing tachycardia.

Key Takeaway:

  • The Bainbridge reflex, also known as the atrial reflex, is a physiological response that causes an increase in heart rate in response to an increase in venous return to the right atrium.
  • This reflex helps to maintain blood pressure and circulation during periods of increased venous return, such as during exercise or when lying down and then standing up.

questions.text: When fluid flows through a narrowed section of a tube, the velocity of the fluid increases, increasing kinetic energy and a corresponding decrease in pressure at that point. Which physical principle best explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The principle mentioned in the above question is the Bernoulli principle.

  • Bernoulli's principle is a fundamental concept in fluid dynamics that describes the relationship between the speed, pressure, and height of a moving fluid. It states that as the speed of a fluid increases, its pressure decreases.

Explanation for other options:

Isohydric principle (Option A): There are several buffers at work in biological fluids at any given time. All buffer pairs in a homogenous solution are in equilibrium with the same [H+]; this is known as the isohydric principle.

Size principle (Option C): The recruitment of motor units during muscle contraction is not random; rather, it follows a general scheme, the size principle. A muscle action is developed by one unit of muscle, then more and more muscle units are added, resulting in a powerful contraction.

Fick's principle (Option D): Fick's principle states that the amount of a substance taken up by an organ (or by the whole body) per unit of time is equal to the arterial level of the substance minus the venous level (A-V difference) times the blood flow.

questions.text: What could be the appropriate reason for the disappearance of Korotkoff sounds during measurement of blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Korotkoff sound disappears when the blood flow becomes laminar as the cuff pressure falls below diastolic pressure and the vessel fully reopens.

  • Korotkoff sounds are produced due to turbulence of the blood flow when the blood vessel is open but not at its fullest.
  • During the blood pressure measurement, when the Korotkoff sound appears after there is no collapse of the vessel, as the lumen gradually increases in size.
  • Vascular resistance slows down the blood flow. It has no direct role in Korotkoff sound production.

Explanation for other options:

Turbulence of the blood flow (Option A): This is the cause for Korotkoff sounds, not their disappearance.

Vascular collapse (Option B): This would obstruct the blood flow entirely, not a normal part of BP measurement.

Vascular resistance (Option D): Affects the blood pressure and not the Korotkoff sound directly.

questions.text: A 46-year-old patient is admitted to the hospital due to sudden hypotension. On evaluation, it is noted that this patient has an ionic imbalance, which causes vasodilation and hypotension. What could not be the cause of such an effect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ionic/metabolic condition that does not cause vasodilation and hypotension is alkalosis.

  • Alkalosis usually causes vasoconstriction, especially cerebral vasoconstriction.
  • It increases excitability and does not typically lead to systemic vasodilation.

Explanation for other options:

Hyperkalemia (Option A): An Increase in potassium ion concentration, within the physiological range, causes vasodilation. This effect results from the ability of potassium ions to inhibit smooth muscle contraction.

Hypermagnesemia (Option B): An increase in magnesium ion concentration causes powerful vasodilation because magnesium ions inhibit smooth muscle contraction.

Hypercapnia (Option D): An increase in carbon dioxide concentration causes moderate vasodilation in most tissues but marked vasodilation in the brain. A slight decrease in hydrogen ion concentration causes arteriolar constriction.

questions.text: The Rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) takes part in the regulation of blood pressure via influencing the autonomic nervous system. Among the following list, which is the factor that inhibits the activity of the RVLM?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Inflation of the lungs causes vasodilation and a decrease in blood pressure. This response is mediated via vagal afferents from the lungs that inhibit RVLM and sympathetic nerve activities.

  • RVLM (Rostral Ventrolateral Medulla) maintains tonic sympathetic vasomotor tone to control blood pressure.
  • It receives both excitatory and inhibitory inputs.

Inhibitory Influence:

  • Pulmonary stretch receptors (activated during lung inflation) stimulate vagal afferents that inhibit RVLM activity via interneurons, thereby reducing sympathetic outflow and lowering BP, which is a part of the Hering-Breuer reflex.

Excitatory Inputs:

Chemoreceptors (A), CO₂ (C), and Pain (D) all increase RVLM activity by:

  • Chemoreceptors → detect hypoxia/acidosis → increase sympathetic tone. (Option A ruled out)
  • CO₂ → acts centrally to stimulate sympathetic drive. (Option C ruled out)
  • Pain → triggers sympathetic stimulation. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: At which of the following mean blood pressures is the maximum discharge from the baroreceptors?
questions.solution:
The discharge from the baroreceptors increases gradually as the mean blood pressure increases above 100 mmHg till 200 mmHg. It is maximum at 200 mmHg of mean arterial pressure.

  • Baroreceptors are present in the carotid and aortic arteries. These receptors are basically inhibitory receptors when stimulated, reduce the blood pressure.
  • At around 100 mmHg of mean blood pressure, the firing from baroreceptors is normal, and they try to maintain the mean blood pressure of 100 mmHg.
  • The discharge from baroreceptors decreases as the mean blood pressure reduces from 100 mmHg to 50 mmHg.

choices.text: It is forced expiration against a closed glottis
On straining, there is a rise in blood pressure due to compression of the aorta.
The decrease in arterial pressure causes tachycardia and an increase in peripheral resistance

questions.text: A 57-year-old male was progressing towards heart failure. The physician advised him with some medicines, along with that, he advised the patient to do the Valsalva manoeuvre. The truth about the Valsalva manoeuvre is
questions.solution:
By increasing the intrathoracic pressure Valsalva manoeuvre reduces the venous return to the heart. So by reducing the workload helps in heart failure.

The following are features of the Valsalva manoeuvre.

  • Forced expiration against a closed glottis occurs in coughing, defecation and heavy lifting. (Option A is true)
  • Initially, blood pressure rises due to an increase in intrathoracic pressure, by increases the pressure over the aorta. (Option B is true)
  • Then it falls because the high intrathoracic pressure compresses the veins, decreasing venous return and cardiac output. The decreases in arterial pressure and pulse pressure inhibit the baroreceptors, causing tachycardia and a rise in peripheral resistance. (Option C is true)
  • When the glottis is opened and the intrathoracic pressure returns to normal, cardiac output is restored, but the peripheral vessels are constricted. It causes blood pressure to rise, leading to baroreceptor stimulation, followed by a decrease in blood pressure and bradycardia.

questions.text: Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres produces profound bradycardia, hypotension and apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This reflex is known as
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Above mentioned reflex is the Bezold-Jarisch reflex, which can be elicited in some pathological conditions like myocardial ischemia and reperfusion as a result of increased production of oxygen radicals.

  • Receptors are found in the juxtacapillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and the pulmonary artery.
  • Varieties of substances like capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, and veratridine also elicit this reflex.

Explanation for other options:

Baroreceptor reflex (Option A): The baroreceptors are stretch receptors in the walls of the heart and blood vessels (carotid sinus and aortic arch). They discharge at an increased rate when the pressure in the carotid sinus and aortic arch rises. It causes a reduction in blood pressure.

Cushing's reflex (Option C): Rise in systemic arterial pressure when the intracranial pressure is increased, leading to local hypercapnia, followed by activation of central chemoreceptors, is known as the Cushing reflex. It causes blood flow to the brain.

Hering-Breuer reflex (Option D): Hering-Breuer reflex is a pulmonary stretch reflex triggered by lung inflation, which is mediated by vagal afferents from lung stretch receptors. It causes inhibition of inspiration to prevent over-inflation of the lungs.

choices.text: Increase in production of HIF-1 alpha

questions.text: A local vasodilation effect of decrease in oxygen tension occurs due to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In most of the tissues, there are local mechanisms that provide the vasodilatation via different mechanisms, like a decrease in oxygen tension and PH.
  • Low oxygen levels can lead to the opening of potassium channels, causing hyperpolarisation and relaxation of smooth muscle, resulting in vasodilation. (Option A is true)
  • Under hypoxic conditions, HIF-1α stabilises and activates transcription of genes that promote angiogenesis and vasodilation, such as VEGF (Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor).
  • Increased release of Histamine causes an increase in capillary permeability, causing local inflammation. (Option C)
  • Adenosine is another vasodilator, especially in cardiac muscles.
  • Rise in temperature, as well as lactate accumulation,can also cause local vasodilation.

choices.text: Relaxation of smooth muscle in the GIT
Promotion of vascular smooth muscle proliferation

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient with long-standing hypertension and stable angina is being evaluated for endothelial function. He has started on nitrates to reduce cardiac workload. Which of the following is not another physiological effect of nitric oxide?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nitric oxide inhibits vascular smooth muscle proliferation, which helps prevent atherosclerosis.

  • Nitric oxide is an endothelium-derived relaxing factor synthesised from arginine via the NO synthase enzyme.
  • There are three isoforms of nitric oxide (1,2,3).

Functions of nitric oxide:

  • NO enhances vascular remodelling and angiogenesis. (Option A ruled out)
  • Penile erection via vasodilation and engorgement of the corpora cavernosa is seen due to the slow breakdown of cyclic GMP. (Option B ruled out)
  • It causes relaxation of gastrointestinal smooth muscle via activation of guanylyl cyclase, increasing cyclic GMP levels. (Option C ruled out)
  • It also inhibits platelet aggregation, reduces leukocyte adhesion, and functions as a neurotransmitter.
  • Tonic release of NO also helps in the maintenance of blood pressure.
  • It is necessary for the antimicrobial and cytotoxic activity induced by cytokines.
